newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel's money supply grew 0.4 pct in November.
newsitem.headline: Israel's money supply grew 0.4 pct in November.

text.p: Israel's M1 money supply grew a preliminary 0.4 percent in November, following a revised 1.5 percent decline in October, the Bank of Israel said on Tuesday.
Since the beginning of the year M1 has expanded by 9.68 percent.

Total credit in November rose 0.6 percent to 248.6 billion shekels, but unlinked shekel credits fell 0.8 percent to 80.7 billion shekels. The increase in overall credit marks a slowing from the monthly rises seen most of this year.
Money supply is one of several figures the Bank of Israel uses to determine short-term interest rates. The central bank's January monetary programme is scheduled to be announced on December 23.

Economists and market analysts have said in recent days that they expect the Bank of Israel to lower the rate by 0.5 percentage points at the end of this month. Further reductions, they say, are likely to come with parliamentary approval of the 1997 budget.
The current base rate is 15.2 percent, which was set at the end of October.
On Sunday, the Central Bureau of Statistics reported that consumer prices rose 0.6 percent in November, following an 0.8 percent rise in October.
